name: Patrick Donahue
demographics: Professionally trained in architecture, design, engineering or related fields
Highly educated and detail-oriented; many with postgraduate specialization or sustainability certifications
Works at small boutique studios, mid-size firms, or global multi-office practices depending on region
business: Leads or contributes to material selection, specification and design intent for architectural projects
Balances aesthetic vision, technical requirements, building codes, engineering constraints and client preferences
Researches materials extensively through digital platforms, case studies, BIM libraries, peers and manufacturers
Evaluates materials based on performance, sustainability credentials, cost, compliance and design impact
Produces drawings, models, and full specification documents to guide contractors and influence final procurement
Coordinates with engineers, contractors, clients and suppliers throughout design and construction
Protects specified materials from substitutions and value engineering during construction
goals: Create distinctive, high-quality, and innovative designs that strengthen their professional reputation
Choose materials that meet design intent, technical performance and sustainability goals
Avoid project failures caused by material underperformance or poor supplier support
Stay current on new materials, sustainable technologies and global design trends
Deliver accurate specifications that reduce risk and avoid costly rework on site
Work with trustworthy suppliers who provide transparent data and fast, knowledgeable support
Build a long-term library of proven materials they can confidently reuse in future projects
pains: Time pressure limits ability to fully explore material options and conduct deep research
Fear that a material will fail, cause delays, or damage their professional reputation
Budget constraints forcing compromise between ideal design and client affordability
Contractors substituting cheaper materials that compromise design intent
Greenwashing and vague sustainability claims with no measurable data
Inconsistent or incomplete technical information from suppliers
Poor responsiveness from manufacturers when issues arise during installation
Difficulty staying updated on rapidly evolving materials and certifications
objections: Rejects suppliers who rely on aggressive sales tactics rather than technical expertise
Avoids brands without transparent performance data, certifications or test results
Dislikes generic corporate marketing with no practical or technical value
Will not specify products with a history of inconsistent quality or logistical unreliability
Skeptical of new materials without proven case studies or peer endorsements
Avoids companies that underestimate the importance of aesthetics and architectural detailing
motivations: Deliver visually striking and technically sound buildings that showcase their design capability
Use sustainable materials that support climate goals, certifications and long-term performance
Collaborate with knowledgeable suppliers who act as technical partners
Access clear, accurate, immediately available technical documentation
Leverage peer recommendations and repeat trusted brands to reduce risk
Specify materials that elevate the project’s aesthetic and performance quality
Gain recognition from clients, peers and the architecture community through innovative project outcomes
channels: Architecture media platforms: ArchDaily, Dezeen, Architectural Record
Search engines for rapid material discovery and case studies
Design and inspiration platforms: Instagram, Pinterest, MaterialBank
BIM libraries, online product directories and CAD resources
Peer networks: firm colleagues, AIA/RIBA/CA associations, online forums
Manufacturer websites with data sheets, BIM objects and technical manuals
Webinars, CEU courses, lunch-and-learn sessions and trade shows
LinkedIn for professional updates, thought leadership and industry trends
quotes: Give me accurate technical data, not marketing fluff.
I need to trust that what I specify will perform exactly as promised.
Innovation is exciting, but only if the material is proven and reliable.
If you can’t answer my technical question quickly, I’ll move on.
A material can be beautiful, but if it fails, it destroys the design.
Show me real case studies—not claims without proof.
regionalNotes: US: Strong emphasis on sustainability standards, certifications, CEU programs and technical rigor.
UK: Heavy focus on energy performance, regulatory compliance and standardized documentation.
Mexico: Deep reliance on peer networks and supplier relationships; Spanish-language content and personal support matter greatly.
Across all: Visual inspiration, technical accuracy and sustainability credentials are decisive factors in specification.
